content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find an Intermediate-level online course on Coursera about 'Blockchain Technology' which lasts between 1 to 4 weeks, and is provided by a well-known institution. Also, note the course's main goals and the instructor's name.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for an intermediate-level online course about 'Blockchain Technology', I should initiate a search using the search function.
Action: Click [2]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is now visible and ready for input. I need to search for 'Blockchain Technology' to find relevant courses.
Action: Type [1]; Blockchain Technology
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Three blockchain-related courses are visible, but their durations are from 3 to 6 months. I need to further filter the results to find courses between 1 and 4 weeks. I should look for a "Duration" filter or similar options, so I need to scroll to search for it.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is a course titled "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD that is beginner-level, lasts 1-4 weeks, and is from a well-known institution. However, we need an intermediate-level course within the 1-4 weeks duration. "6G Evolution: Blockchain, Semantic Communications & Radar" by the University of Glasgow is intermediate but set at 1-3 months, which exceeds 4 weeks. I should check if there are more relevant intermediate options, possibly by scrolling further or refining filters.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The courses displayed are either beginner-level or exceed the required duration. There is currently no intermediate-level course within 1-4 weeks visible. I should look for filtering or sorting options that may help target intermediate level and 1-4 week duration more directly.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The filters for subject and language are visible, but there are no visible filters for "Level" or "Duration" that would help to narrow down specifically to intermediate-level and 1-4 week duration. Only one course, "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD, fits the duration and institution requirement but is labeled as beginner, not intermediate. To check if such filters exist and can be applied, I should look for more filter options, likely by exploring the rest of the available filters.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The left sidebar contains subject and language filters, but no visible filter for course level or duration. The central course cards include one intermediate-level course ("Blockchain" by University at Buffalo), but its duration is 3-6 months, not the required 1-4 weeks. Additional filtering options might be found by scrolling or clicking, especially for duration and level.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am again seeing the previous set of results. The only visible intermediate-level course is "6G Evolution: Blockchain, Semantic Communications & Radar" (by University of Glasgow), but it lasts 1-3 months. The only course fitting the duration requirement (1-4 weeks) is beginner level. There is no visible filter for "Level" or "Duration" to narrow down further, but there might be more filters if I scroll or interact with filter expansion buttons like "Show 3 more."
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Expanding the subject filters did not reveal any new options for filtering by level or duration. The course "6G Evolution: Blockchain, Semantic Communications & Radar" is intermediate but does not match the required duration (1-4 weeks). All other options fitting the week duration are beginner level. For completeness, I should check the filter area below for possible duration/level filters.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The newly visible courses still do not fit the requirements—none are intermediate level within 1-4 weeks; all displayed are beginner-level and/or longer in duration. The filter sidebar does not show level or duration filters. I should try scrolling down further to check if more filtering options for level or duration exist below the language filters.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is a course titled "Blockchain Business Models" by Duke University that is intermediate level and titled as a "Course," not a specialization. Its duration is listed as 1-3 months, which might still be longer than the requested 1-4 weeks, but is the shortest intermediate course seen so far, and it is from a well-known institution. No intermediate-level course within the required 1-4 weeks has been found, but this is the closest match visible.
Action: Click [29]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.85

The main course title is visible, but the course's main goals/learning objectives are not shown in this view. Additional course information (goals, syllabus, details) is likely lower on the page, so I should scroll down to find these details.

Thought: The course is intermediate-level, with a flexible schedule of 1 week at 10 hours a week, so the duration (likely 1-4 weeks based on intensity) fits the requirement. The displayed skills ("Financial Regulation," "Blockchain," "Due Diligence," "Compliance," etc.) indicate the main goals of the course. This page provides all required information except possibly a more detailed course goal/objective (which might be in the "Outcomes" or "About" tabs if more specificity is required). The instructor's name ("Campbell R. Harvey") was obtained earlier.
Action: Click [6]
Confidence: 0.9

Thought: The "Outcomes" tab confirms the main goals of the course: learning new industry concepts, gaining foundational understanding, developing job-relevant skills, and earning a career certificate. This page provides a clear summary of what students will achieve. I now have all the required information: course title, level, institution, instructor, duration, and main goals.
Action: ANSWER; 
Course: Blockchain Business Models  
Institution: Duke University  
Level: Intermediate  
Duration: Flexible (1 week at 10 hours/week; typically 1-4 weeks with this pace)  
Instructor: Campbell R. Harvey  
Main Goals:  
- Learn new concepts from industry experts  
- Gain a foundational understanding of blockchain and its business models  
- Develop job-relevant skills with hands-on projects  
- Earn a shareable career certificate  
Skills include: Financial Regulation, Blockchain, Due Diligence, Regulatory Compliance, Innovation, Digital Assets, Encryption, and more.
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
